Well, assuming docks sound can't echo, which i'll take your word for, it would probably have something to do with the frequncey the dock makes noises at and the absorbtion of the precussion's energy by the surrounding enviroment. Echos work by having sound waves get bounced around and the precussion of air is send back to you seemingly stornger because it has bounced off most of the walls. A dock, agian assuming your right, might generate noise at a level easily absorbed by enviroments or materials that normally reflect sound at our normal voice octaves.

Why does pain hurt?

 pain is your body's way of telling your brain that something is wrong there. its uncomfortable (painful) to be in pain because its in your body's best interest to change or remove whatever is painful.
 
 if you step on a splinter, the pain signals that something is wrong with your foot, even though none of your other senses could have possibly detected it (you couldnt see or hear the splinter penetration). you would immediately (reflexively) pull your foot away and tend to it. also, the continuous pain until the cut heals will remind you not to put pressure on that part of the foot. when the cut is healed, the pain stops
 
 for your survival sake, you should be very grateful for pain. imagine bleeding to death from stepping on a splinter and not knowing...

Sorry, meant ducks!

 
 So now I will answer your question. What does rotten meat taste bad? Why do my eyes uncontrollably blink when I try to stare at the sun? Why do I feel hungry when I haven't eaten in a long time? Why does pain hurt?
 
 All these things are answered in the same way. It is all a part of being able to survive. If pain didn't hurt then you would cause damage to yourself without knowing it. If rotten meat didn't taste bad then you would eat it and get sick or die. If you didn't blink when looking at the sun you would go blind. If you didn't feel hungry after not eating for a long period of time you would starve. It is all survival instincts. I'm sure you already knew this which is why I can't help but wonder why you asked the question in the first place.

A better question is why are ducks the only creatures whose sound cannot create an echo?

 That is factually incorrect. An echo simply occurs when sound waves are reflected - normally a hard surface. It's just that things with a lower frequency do not echo as well. Which, I think, is what the quack of a duck is. ;)
 
 Found a good link:
 http://www.acoustics.salford.ac.uk/acoustics_world/duck/duck.htm

 Well that solves that question. Now, an interesting question is: does there exist a sound that generates no echo?
 
 If yes, what is it?
 If no, why not?

Well that solves that question. Now, an interesting question is: does there exist a sound that generates no echo?
 
 If yes, what is it?
 If no, why not?

 Id say no, simply because all sounds are waves, and all waves can be reflected. its much easier to hear the echo of a loud sudden sound that a quieter, subtle fading sound
 
 however, if you had a continuous monotonus hum forever, you would not hear an echo, even if you surrounded it in reflective surfaces. and like the article says, with sounds that fade in and fade out and are more or less monotonuous its difficult to hear an echo

Id say no, simply because all sounds are waves, and all waves can be reflected. its much easier to hear the echo of a loud sudden sound that a quieter, subtle fading sound
 
 however, if you had a continuous monotonus hum forever, you would not hear an echo, even if you surrounded it in reflective surfaces. and like the article says, with sounds that fade in and fade out and are more or less monotonuous its difficult to hear an echo

 
 Correct. All sound waves, which are percussion waves, can be reflected, it is simply a matter of the frequency (energy) of the sound and the material it is reflecting off of. Higher energy sounds reflect more easily whereas lower energy are more easily absorbed. Some materials more readily absorb while others more readily reflect.

Pain hurts becuase it is, almost always, bad for your body, The body has adapted so that when we are hurt we feel pain, so much so that it makes us do anything to stop whatevers hurting us and to fix it.
 
 Same with pleasure, pleasurable things, such as sex, are usuallly good, we are encouraged by our nature to procreate as much as possible as necceary to survivle of the species.

Pain is both a warning signal to get us out of danger but do not forget it discourages you from exposing the body from harm for no benefit. Pain causes mental scarring because it is suposed to create fear, sometimes it gets out of hand but in the wild you would be alot better of with pain.

 i dont know if you'd call it mental scarring, or why... every time you experience something, it leaves an imprint in your mind. thats how you learn things or remeber information. "mental scarring" is essential, otherwise you'd have to learn to drive, tie your shoes, and even feed yourself, every day.
 
 pain's purpose is not to create fear. i've been burnt by hot oil, but i dont fear frying eggs. i've learned the correct way to do it without getting burnt. without "mental scars" we'd get burnt everyday. think about it
You guys should watch Mythbusters. The duck quack myth was busted in Episode 8. :p

Why does pain hurt?

 
 Pain is hurt, pain itself doesn't "hurt".
 
 Why is there pain? It aids survival. Simplest example are people born without the ability to feel pain. They have a distinct survival disadvantage. Pain is the feedback we get from our body, without it, it's open-loop.
 
 Logically, pain must be. If you instead felt PLEASURE, from putting your hand on a hot stove, your ancestors would have died from infected burns long ago, if not from suicidal immolation directly. Pain = avoid/something is wrong, pleasure = seek/something is good. Simple control mechanisms, hard to make any real-world system without them, it's only natural.
 
 -Mach

Well consider couple of these points:
 Pain is considered "good", "holy" and even "sexual" in a lot of different cultures. It could be a warning but it's meaning has been manipulated by cultural perception of pain. Also pain is an emotion it is a feeling it's kinda like fear it's bases are in a mental realm not physical. That is why drugs could be given to a human to tranquilize the brain. The argument on a nature of mental and physical states is an old question indeed and has been discussed by many philosophers. I tend to be a property dualist but vary on my perception of mind vs brain. Now my question is if pain is a warning mechanism and we are build for maximal survival then why can we over write the pain with our minds in activities such as meditation?(isn't that illogical) 
 
 -Mala Fide

Well consider couple of these points:
 Pain is considered "good", "holy" and even "sexual" in a lot of different cultures. It could be a warning but it's meaning has been manipulated by cultural perception of pain. Also pain is an emotion it is a feeling it's kinda like fear it's bases are in a mental realm not physical. That is why drugs could be given to a human to tranquilize the brain. The argument on a nature of mental and physical states is an old question indeed and has been discussed by many philosophers. I tend to be a property dualist but vary on my perception of mind vs brain. Now my question is if pain is a warning mechanism and we are build for maximal survival then why can we over write the pain with our minds in activities such as meditation?(isn't that illogical) 
 
 -Mala Fide

 
 No, it's not illogical, where is the contradiction?
 
 The human mind (and many other animal brains), is amazingly adaptable. 
 Further, conciousness by in large can override a lot of the primitive programming. This is a survival benefit. Take sex for example. It's intensly pleasurable, good to seek it. But if those sexual desires were to be followed when the conscious mind might calculate it's "not a good time", you might have situations where some animal mates, because they are programmed to, despite the predator that is charging them...
 The mind's ability to control "most" actions, is more adaptive than without it.
 
 In reality, pain comes in varying degrees. Humans can override most senses through "distraction" of some form or another, however, part of the brain still experiences the sensory input. Take hypnosis for example. Some hypnotized patients that are exposed to pain that normally results in a reflexive reaction, don't react. However, if asked "do you feel this, is it painful", they can tell you it is. Did they "override" the pain? Not really, they just compartmentalized it, so to speak. Same goes with meditation. A headache? OK, I can see it. A jagged blade shoved under a finger nail? I'm doubting you can just lotus-power that away...
 
 Ever seen the experiments with split brain patients? You might find it fascinating given your interestin brain duality.
 
 -Mach

Pain hurts only because you think about it. For example, I tryed this on myself, I took a knife, and pushed the point into my arm for has hard as i could stand thinkin about the pain, then, i chose a different spot on my arm and did the same thing, but at the same time I talked with a friend and watch the television, eventualy, i forgot the knife was there, when I remembered, its was because I was bleeding. Now, you may say "well how come when im doing something and something htis me or something it hurts." That is because you are aware of the thing around you until something you arent aware of becomes apparent to you in a mere second. There are exceptions to this statment however, like extreme pain such as a limb being severd or burning.

pain hurts for the reason of self preservation. It is there so you do not do something that will dammage your body and incapacitate you or cause death. It is your brain saying to your body "you XXXXX, dont do that!"

There are exceptions to this statment however, like extreme pain such as a limb being severd or burning.

 i agree that pain can be mastered. pain is subject to your brain's interpretation, and anything subject to your brain's processing can be controlled either consciously, or subconsciously with the development of a habit (ie., getting accustomed to ignoring/rejecting pain)
